qas.question: Jewish law includes which principle used to justify copyright?
When did Jewish law recognize copyright?
How long was a patent valid in Sybaris?

plausible_answers.text: the principle of Hasagat Ge'vul (unfair encroachment)

qas.question: What Jewish principle justified copyright in 500 BCE?
How long was the patent offered by Jewish law?
A Jewish law considered intellectual creations to be what?

context: The concept's origins can potentially be traced back further. Jewish law includes several considerations whose effects are similar to those of modern intellectual property laws, though the notion of intellectual creations as <b7_0>property<b7_0/> does not seem to exist – notably <b4_0>the principle of <a0_0>Hasagat Ge'vul (unfair encroachment)<b4_0/><a0_0/> was used to justify limited-term publisher (but not author) copyright <a1_0>in the 16th century<a1_0/>. In <a2_0>500 BCE<a2_0/>, the government of the Greek state of <b6_0>Sybaris<b6_0/> offered <a3_0><b5_0>one year<b5_0/><a3_0/>'s patent "to all who should discover any new refinement in luxury".
